unnormalised: Understanding tax filing and compliance is crucial for every Indian citizen and business. Navigating the intricacies of the Income Tax Act, 1961, can seem daunting, but with the right knowledge, it becomes a manageable process. This article aims to provide an educational overview of key aspects of tax filing and compliance in India.

unnormalised: The first step is understanding the different types of taxes. Direct taxes, such as Income Tax and Corporate Tax, are levied directly on income and profits. Indirect taxes, like GST (Goods and Services Tax), are levied on the sale of goods and services. For individuals, Income Tax is the primary concern. The Income Tax Department, under the Ministry of Finance, governs these matters. Every individual earning above the basic exemption limit (Rs. 250000 for FY 2023-24 under the old regime) is required to file an Income Tax Return (ITR).

unnormalised: Filing an ITR involves declaring your income from various sources, such as salary, business, house property, and capital gains. It also involves claiming deductions under sections like 80C, 80D, and 80G. Section 80C allows deductions up to Rs. 1.5 lakh for investments like PPF, NSC, and ELSS. Section 80D provides deductions for medical insurance premiums, while Section 80G covers donations to charitable organizations. The last date for filing ITR without penalty is usually 31st July, but this date can be extended by the government. For AY 2024-25, the extended date was 30th September for certain categories.

unnormalised: There are different ITR forms depending on the nature of your income. ITR-1 (Sahaj) is for individuals with income from salary, one house property, and other sources. ITR-2 is for individuals and HUFs not having income from business or profession. ITR-3 is for individuals and HUFs having income from business or profession. ITR-4 (Sugam) is for individuals, HUFs, and firms (other than LLP) having income from business or profession under presumptive taxation scheme. These forms are available on the Income Tax Department's e-filing portal.

unnormalised: Compliance goes beyond just filing ITR. It includes paying advance tax if your estimated tax liability exceeds Rs. 10000. Advance tax is payable in installments on 15th June, 15th September, 15th December, and 15th March. Failure to pay advance tax attracts interest under section 234B. Similarly, delay in filing ITR attracts penalty under section 234F, which can be Rs. 5000 for returns filed after the due date but before 31st December, and Rs. 10000 thereafter.

unnormalised: Another crucial aspect is TDS (Tax Deducted at Source). TDS is deducted by the payer on various payments like salary, interest, rent, and professional fees. The deductee can claim credit for TDS while filing ITR. Form 26AS is an important document that reflects the TDS deducted from your income. It is essential to reconcile Form 26AS with your income details before filing ITR.

T-D-S is deducted by the payer on various payments like salary, interest, rent, and professional fees. the deductee can claim credit for T-D-S while filing I-T-R. Form twenty six A-S is an important document that reflects the T-D-S deducted from your income. it is essential to reconcile Form twenty six A-S with your income details before filing I-T-R.

unnormalised: E-verification is mandatory after filing ITR. You can e-verify your return through Aadhaar OTP, net banking, or digital signature. If you fail to e-verify your return within 120 days, it will be considered invalid. It's advisable to keep all relevant documents, such as salary slips, bank statements, and investment proofs, for at least 6 years as the Income Tax Department can issue a notice for scrutiny.

unnormalised: In conclusion, understanding and adhering to tax laws is not just a legal obligation but also a civic duty. By staying informed, seeking professional advice when needed, and utilizing the resources provided by the Income Tax Department, taxpayers can ensure seamless tax filing and compliance. Remember to file your ITR well before the deadline and keep all your documents in order.
